issues.description: The solution's GET /persons endpoint requires an additional required query parameter 'limit' that is not mentioned in the problem statement and is not sent by the client. The problem statement and Part 3 only describe passing sortField and sortingOrder as query parameters (with defaults). The solution's PersonResource.getAllPersons has a required @RequestParam(value = "limit") int limit and then returns a subList(0, Math.min(limit, allPersons.size())). However the client implementation (PersonController.getAllPersons) builds a request with only sortField and sortingOrder and does not provide a 'limit' parameter. This mismatch will cause requests from the provided client to the server to fail (HTTP 400 due to the missing required parameter) and thus breaks the intended end-to-end behavior.

The problem statement (lines 150-151) says "Each method takes a Consumer<List<Note>> parameter... This consumer takes the internal list of persons as a parameter", which incorrectly names the generic parameter as List<Note> instead of List<Person>. The template and solution PersonController methods use Consumer<List<Person>>. This copy-paste/identifier mismatch between the problem description and the code can confuse students about the expected types and which controller (notes vs. persons) the text refers to.
issues.suggested_fix: Correct the problem statement to refer to Consumer<List<Person>> (not Consumer<List<Note>>) when describing the PersonController methods. For example: "Each method takes a Consumer<List<Person>> parameter, which has to be called after a response is received — this consumer takes the internal list of persons as a parameter." This aligns the textual description with the template and solution code and removes potential confusion.
